awd_titl_txt: Semi-annual Workshop in Dynamical Systems and Related Topics at Penn State
awd_abstract_narration:
Katok DMS-1800679 

This award provides funding for participants in ``Semi-annual Workshop in Dynamical Systems and Related Topics at Penn State'' for the three years 2018, 2019, and 2020. The workshop is devoted to recent developments in dynamical systems and many applications to other disciplines. The workshop has been funded by NSF for the past ten years. The workshop always attracts a considerable number of participants from other regions of the United States and other countries. Approximately 20 junior participants will be supported each year.

More information will be made available at: https://math.psu.edu/dynsys/workshop

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. The Fall Workshop in Dynamical Systems and Related Topics represents Penn State's half of the Semiannual Workshop in Dynamical Systems and Related Topics, co-sponsored by the dynamics groups of Penn State and University of Maryland, College Park. The Penn State meeting takes place each fall since its inception in 1990, and the Maryland meeting is held each spring since 1992. These days they are major conferences in dynamical systems in the United States that attract many outstanding researchers as well as many young scientists, postdocs and graduate students. The talks given at these workshops cover essentially all areas of dynamics and represent the front line of research.

Among the past speakers at the fall conference were prominent mathematicians such as A. Brown, V. Bergelson, D. Damjanovic, M. Denker, S. Dyatlov, M. Einsiedler, A. Eskin, B. Fayad, S. Filip, H. Furstenberg, M. Gerber, A. Gorodetski, S. Gouezel, S. B. Hasselblatt, H. Hofer, S. Jitomirskaya, R. Krikorian, E. Lindenstrauss, H. Oh, M. Pollicott, P. Sarnak, R. Spatzier, T. Tao, J.-P. Thouvenot, B. Weiss, A. Wilkinson, in addition to members of the Penn State and Maryland groups.

In all our meetings we have  included talks from widely varying areas of dynamical systems and related areas in geometry, analysis, topology, etc. The highlights of 2019 and 2021 meetings were presentations of the 8th and the 10th Michael Brin Prize in Dynamical Systems to Sebastien Gouezel and Tim Austin, respectively. Saturday afternoon session of these meetings featured the award ceremony and two talks dedicated to the award winning work and other achievements of the winners given by prominent experts in the field. The 2018 meeting was dedicated to the memory of Anatole Katok who was an initiator of the Penn State meetings as well as joint activity and collaboration between Penn State and Maryland dynamical groups. This meeting featured a Special Session: Inauguration of Anatole Katok Center for Dynamical Systems and Geometry. Additional funding for this meeting was provided by the Anatole Katok Center for Dynamical Systems and Geometry at Penn State, Eberly College of Science and Department of Mathematics at Penn State. The 2018 and 2020 meetings featured presentations of the 2nd and the 3rd Michael Brin Dynamical Systems Prize for Young Mathematicians to Alex Wright and Brandon Seward, and to Joel Moreira and talks by the winners. 2019 meeting featured Special Session on Katok-Spatzier Global Rigidity Conjecture, 2020 meeting featured Special Session "New trends in thermodynamic formalism", 2021 meeting held a Special session in memory of Viorel Nitica and a Special Session dedicated to the 15th anniversary of Journal of Modern Dynamics.

Broader Impact. A primary goal of our conference is to contribute to the training of graduate students and recent Ph.D.s and to their integration into the dynamics community. Typically 15 to 20 graduate students attend the conference and 4 to 8 of them give short talks on the recommendation of their advisors. There are always solid groups of students from Penn State University and the University of Maryland, and recently also from Ohio State University, University of Houston, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, and University of Chicago. Special efforts were made to attract female participants as well as members of underrepresented groups. Some of our meetings featured poster sessions where young participants presented their recent results. We generally schedule talks by students and recent Ph.D. recipients  in parallel sessions, but never more than two speakers at a time. In organizing the conference a special attention is given to reimbursing expenses of graduate students and postdocs. In addition to the usual lodging coverage we provide the cost of transportation for junior participants driving in carpools.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2022
Modified by: Svetlana Katok
